12890894330569

845942757490737

Specie 1222 then disappears.

Ta

Matt

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Matt Simmerson" <m.simmerson@b...> wrote:
> Hi Philip
> 
> It was a contrived example, but is representative of actual events.  
> 
> You say you wouldn't expect such small species with such good fitnes,
> but if it's a young specie, it may well be very small as a break away
> (mutation) from a larger species.
> 
> This happens regardless of whether the compatability value remains
> constant (and specie numbers vary) or the compatability score varies
> whilst trying to keep the specie count constant. 
> 
> Ta
> 
> Matt
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Philip Tucker <ptucker@g...> wrote:
> > Was this a contrived example to illustrate your point, or did you
> > actually witness numbers this extreme in practice?  My guess is that
> > the population would never reach such an extreme dichotomy between
> > species because specie 3 never would have gotten that large unless its
> > fitness were dominating the others - which in this case it is not. 
> > Also, the species 1 and 2 likely would not be that small with such
> > good fitness.
> > 
> > - Philip
> > 
> > On 8/19/05, Matt Simmerson <m.simmerson@b...> wrote:
> > > Hi
> > > 
> > > Whilst calculating the number of offspring for a valid (i.e. non
> > > extinct and size > 0) specie, the count returns 0.  This is
> > > particularly prevalent in large species where the adjusted fitness
> > > becomes quite small comapared with the rest of the other, and
usually
> > > much less populous, species.
> > > 
> > > This becomes even more marked if I boost young species fitness.
> > > 
> > > As far as I understand, the offspring is calculated as follows.
> > > 
> > > (av adjusted specie fitness) / (total of all species av adjusted
> > > fitnesses) * Population size.
> > > 
> > > For example, imagine we have 3 species. Specie_1 has 3 members
av raw
> > > fitness 0.85, Specie_2 has 2 members av raw fitness 0.82 and
Specie_3
> > > has 145 members with av raw fitness 0f 0.9.
> > > 
> > > Specie_1(adj) = 0.85/3 = 0.28333
> > > Specie_2(adj) = 0.82/2 = 0.41
> > > Specie_3(adj) = 0.9/145 = 0.006
> > > 
> > > Specie_1 then generates 61 offspring
> > > Specie_2 then generates 87 offspring
> > > Specie_3 then generates 2 offspring
> > > 
> > > Not quite 0, but you get the idea.  So even though the largest
specie
> > > with has best average fitness, its population gets decimated.
> > > 
> > > I understand, that large species need to get penalised, but this
seems
> > > extreme and you are potentially losing a lot of good gemomes.
> > > 
> > > Ideas/correction/thoughts appreciated.
> > > 
> > > Ta
> > > 
> > > Matt
> > > 
> > > 
> > > 
> > >
